repnme.cdata!:
Lao - Southern Provinces Rural
            Electrification Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating is moderately
            satisfactory, because of EdL's unsatisfactory financial
            performance for most of the project's duration and the
            technical problems. Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            that of the borrower moderately satisfactory (again
            reflecting EdL's poor financial performance). The risk
            to development outcome is modest since measures implemented
            toward the end of, and  subsequent to, project completion
            have addressed the financial sustainability issue, and
            technical issues are being addressed under the follow-on
            Rural Electrification Project. The main lessons from this
            review are as follows: (i) the consumers are willing to pay
            tariffs at cost recovery levels, and the willingness to pay
            analysis shows that consumers are willing to pay for
            electricity at levels exceeding supply costs. Lao PDR has
            been able to implement sizeable tariff increases in a short
            space of time with no adverse social impact or notable
            demand reductions (indeed it can be argued that any
            reduction in usage by already connected customers would help
            extend supply to new locations); (ii) but poorer households
            remain unconnected, even after the grid has been in a
            village for more than 10 years, some 20 percent of
            households remain unconnected. Smart (i.e. efficiently
            targeted) connection subsidies for late connectors will help
            achieve government's 90 percent coverage target; and
            (iii) explicit attention needs to be paid to technical
            efficiency, and technical problems of system losses and
            outages reduce financial performance and undermine project
            benefits. Explicit components are needed to tackle such issues.

Lao - Southern Provinces Rural
            Electrification Project

repnme.cdata!:
Providing electricity to poor rural
            provinces of Lao PDR

abstracts.cdata!:
The project was set out to provide
            electricity to seven poor rural provinces of Lao
            People's Democratic Republic (PDR) and strengthen the
            capacity of the country's sole electricity provider,
            electricite du Laos (EdL), to expand its reach to the rural
            poor through electrification investments and to operate on a
            commercial basis. International Development Association
            (IDA) resources provided the EdL with the needed investment
            to expand its network, while helping it become financially
            sounder through improved cost recovery efforts. IDA also
            supported the ministry of energy and mines to pilot and
            establish sustainable off-grid electrification delivery
            systems. IDA established close working relationships with
            key policy makers in reforming the power sector. The project
            applied innovative techniques to connect households in very
            remote areas. Solar home systems and small, village-based
            hydro schemes helped electrify more than 6,000 households in
            villages without grid coverage. Building on the success of
            this project, IDA plans to continue its support to the
            government through two rural electrification projects and a
            Greater Mekong sub-region power trade project.

TF020056-GEF1 MSP LAO--PDR SOUTHERN

repnme.cdata!:
Lao - Southern Provinces Rural
            Electrification Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Regardless of success, it
            is re-emphasized that Government commitment should be
            addressed early on, strongly ensured through a comprehensive
            risk assessment, while lessons indicate the following.
            Project design should have taken into account the
            house-wiring costs, due to highly negative connection rates,
            as well as high prices faced by customers; therefore, a
            House Wiring Affordability Plan is suggested (to be
            introduced in the following operation), which would reduce
            prices through increased competition and price regulation,
            including provisions of term payments by the poorest 20
            percent of customers. In this context, charges by private
            firms to connect households to EdL (Electricite du Laos)
            grid after the electrification of villages need to be
            regulated. Notwithstanding, investments in loss reduction
            were effective, as well as enhanced measures, including,
            inter alia, the use of state-of-the-art software and
            hardware, and project evaluation technologies for reducing
            technical losses, which will be introduced in the following
            operation. However, problems (which largely arose due to the
            position of the Off-Grid Promotion Support Office (OPS) as a
            government office) such as delay in centralized procurement,
            lack of effectiveness in management of non-performing
            Provincial Electricity Services Companies (PESCOs), could be
            overcome by contracting out the OPS' daily operational
            functions for the off-grid program. Moreover, financially,
            through the off-grid component, it has been found that the
            private sector in Lao PDR is unwilling to make long-term
            capital investments, although it will contribute working capital.

TF020056-GEF1 MSP LAO--PDR SOUTHERN
            PROVINCES RURAL ELECTRIFICATION,TF033494-LAOS - EDL POWER DISTRIBUTION,TF033794-LAOS - ENERGY, POWER,TF023485-USDOE-ALTERNATIVE ENERGY ACTIVITIES
5083839.majtheme: Rule of law,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Southern Provinces Rural
            Electrification Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Southern Provinces
            Rural Electrification Project for Laos are to 1) expand
            rural electricity service in 7 central and southern
            provinces where economically justified, through grid
            extension and off-grid electrification; and 2) strengthen
            the electric company's (EDL) capacity to plan and
            implement electrification investments and to operate on a
            commercial basis. The project's components are three:
            1) The Distribution Extension component will finance
            lower-cost extension of the distribution grid in rural areas
            and small towns, as well as a subtransmission system to
            electrify areas; 2) The Off-Grid Rural Electrification
            component will pilot standalone electricity systems
            including renewable energy technologies, and will develop a
            national plan for off-grid rural electrification; and 3) the
            Institution Building component will support EDL in project
            management and commercialization, and will provide
            assistance to the government in sector planning and further commercialization.

docna.cdata!:
Laos - Southern Provinces Rural
            Electrification Project

display_title.display_title:
Laos - Southern Provinces Rural
            Electrification Project
